Let $A\subseteq \mathbb{N}$ be an infinite arithmetic progression and $f:A\to \{-1,1\}$ be a non-constant function. Must there exist a finite non-empty $S\subset A$ such that\[\sum_{n\in S}\frac{f(n)}{n}=0?\]What about if $A$ is an arbitrary set of positive density? What if $A$ is the set of squares excluding $1$?



Erd\H{o}s and Straus \cite{ErSt75} proved this when $A=\mathbb{N}$. Sattler \cite{Sa75} proved this when $A$ is the set of odd numbers. For the squares $1$ must be excluded or the result is trivially false, since\[\sum_{k\geq 2}\frac{1}{k^2}<1.\]This is false for some sets $A$ of positive density - indeed, it fails for any set $A$ containing exactly one even number. (Sattler \cite{Sa82} credits this observation to Erd\H{o}s, who presumably found this after \cite{ErGr80}.)

Sattler \cite{Sa82b} proved the answer to the original question is yes, in that any arithmetic progression has this property.

The final question of the set of squares excluding $1$ appears to be open - Sattler announced a proof in \cite{Sa82} and \cite{Sa82b}, but this never appeared.




References


[ErGr80] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Graham, R., Old and new problems and results in combinatorial number theory. Monographies de L'Enseignement Mathematique (1980).

[ErSt75] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Straus, E. G., Solution to Problem 387. Nieuw Arch. Wisk. (1975), 183.

[Sa75] Sattler, R., Solution to Problem 387. Nieuw Arch. Wisk. (1975), 184-189.

[Sa82] Sattler, R., On {E}rd\H{o}s property {${\rm P}\sb{1}$}\ for the sequence of
squarefree numbers. Nederl. Akad. Wetensch. Indag. Math. (1982), 341--346.

[Sa82b] Sattler, R., On {E}rd\H{o}s property {${\rm P}\sb{1}$}\ for the arithmetical
sequence. Nederl. Akad. Wetensch. Indag. Math. (1982), 347--352.
